transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by discussing the homework from our last session. You mentioned that you practiced mindfulness and grounding techniques and filled out some thought records. Can you share with me how those exercises went for you?

Patient: The mindfulness and grounding techniques were helpful when I remembered to do them. I found that focusing on my breath or using my senses to ground myself in the present moment helped to calm me down when I was feeling overwhelmed. But I struggled to remember to do them in the moment when I was really stressed or anxious.

Therapist: That's a common challenge when starting to use these techniques. It takes practice to make them a habit. One strategy that can help is to schedule specific times throughout the day to practice mindfulness, even when you're not feeling particularly stressed. This can help make it a more automatic response when you do start to feel overwhelmed. What about the thought records? How did those go?

Patient: I filled out a few thought records, but I found it challenging to identify the cognitive distortions in the moment. I was able to do it when I sat down and really thought about it, but it was harder to do when I was in the middle of feeling anxious or depressed.

Therapist: That's understandable. Identifying cognitive distortions takes practice, and it can be especially challenging when you're in the midst of intense emotions. One thing that can help is to start by just noticing your thoughts without trying to label them right away. Simply acknowledging the thoughts and writing them down can be a powerful first step. As you continue to practice, it will become easier to identify the distortions. Did you notice any patterns or themes in the thoughts you recorded?

Patient: I noticed that I have a lot of thoughts related to not being good enough or not being able to handle things. I have a lot of fear about failing or disappointing people.

Therapist: Those are common themes for many people, and they can be particularly distressing. In CBT, we call these types of thoughts "automatic thoughts" because they tend to pop up automatically without us even realizing it. Often, these automatic thoughts are influenced by deeper beliefs we hold about ourselves, others, and the world. These deeper beliefs are called "core beliefs." Can you think of any core beliefs that might be underlying the automatic thoughts you noticed?

Patient: I think I have a core belief that I'm not good enough, that I'm somehow fundamentally flawed or deficient. I also have a belief that if I don't succeed, people will reject or abandon me.

Therapist: Those are powerful beliefs, and they can have a big impact on how we feel and behave. In CBT, we work on identifying and challenging these beliefs, as well as the automatic thoughts they influence. By doing so, we can start to shift our perspective and develop more balanced and helpful ways of thinking. Would you like to explore this further?

Patient: Yes, I think that would be really helpful. I know these beliefs are holding me back, but I'm not sure how to change them.

Therapist: One way we can start to shift these beliefs is by looking for evidence that contradicts them. For example, can you think of any times in your life when you succeeded at something or handled a challenge well, even if it wasn't perfect?

Patient: Well, I did manage to graduate from college and get my Master's degree, even though it was really challenging at times. And I've been able to maintain my sobriety for several years now, which is something I'm proud of.

Therapist: Those are significant accomplishments, and they provide strong evidence against the belief that you're not good enough. Recognizing and reminding yourself of these types of experiences can help to weaken the hold of those negative core beliefs. Another strategy is to actively look for experiences that contradict the belief. For example, you could try taking on a small challenge or trying something new, even if it feels uncomfortable, and pay attention to how it goes. This can provide new evidence to counter the old belief. How does that sound to you?

Patient: It sounds like it could be helpful, but it also feels scary. I'm worried that if I try something and fail, it will just confirm my belief that I'm not good enough.

Therapist: That's a common fear, and it's understandable. One way to approach this is to start with very small, manageable challenges and gradually work up to bigger ones. This is called "graded exposure." By starting small and building up gradually, you can build confidence and resilience over time. And even if things don't go perfectly, you can learn from the experience and use it to inform your next attempt. What do you think about that approach?

Patient: It makes sense, and it feels less overwhelming to think about starting small. I guess I could start by just researching some options for teaching or reaching out to someone in the field to learn more about their experience.

Therapist: That's a great idea! Taking small, concrete steps like that can be really helpful in building momentum and confidence. And remember, the goal isn't to be perfect or to never make mistakes. The goal is to learn and grow, even when things are challenging. I'm here to support you in that process.

Patient: Thank you, that means a lot. I know it won't be easy, but I'm willing to try.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear. Your willingness to engage in this process, even when it's difficult, is a strength. Remember to be patient and compassionate with yourself as you work on challenging these old beliefs and building new ones. It takes time and practice, but it is possible to change these patterns of thinking.
